moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Nf6 3. Nf3 e6 4. dxe6 B: This disables the otherwise good Qe7, since white has a tempo more to castle.
moves.5... c5: If white plays Nc3, a6 must be played to stop the Nb5 jump.
moves.6. O-O Bd6: Controlling e5, in time to play a6 if needed.
moves.10... Qc7: h2 is also a target. Unfortunately, I have castled, so h5 is not as good.
moves.11. h3 h6 12. Nf3: NO point in pushing the N on the proper square to guard h2, and no point in checking the king: Bh2+, Kh1, then something like Nd7, tempting white to go g3 (to trap the bishop), but Bxh3, etc. can be a classic winning sac.
moves.12... Nbd7 13. b3: White goes for mounting a dangerous carabine on g7.
moves.13... Ne5: This N is almost useless for me, so I better exchange it. Or sac it.
moves.14. Bb2 Nxf3+: I still didn't see a clear winning sac here.
moves.15. Bxf3: Now white has an edge, with those bishops pointing to weak points... I started to blunder. My revenge was d3, but for some reason I thought at once that white could defend it, so I went for another thing.
The idea is to tempt white to play g3.
moves.20. Bxb7: And now the idea is to gain some time to build an attack while white goes pawn's grabbing. Of course, this implies I have to win.
moves.22. Rad1 Bf5 23. d4 cxd4 24. Bxd4 Be4: This was the idea. Now MY bishops seem powerful and looking to the WK.
moves.25. Qg4 Bg6 26. Bb5: White has to lose a couple of tempos to get his other bishop into the actor or to move the pawns (the best he could have done, anyway).
moves.26... Re6 27. a4 f5: Using his queen to push my pawns forward.
moves.28. Qf3 Red6: ?? I just blundered the bishop. Mi opponent though about who ever knows what a hidden trap, and didn't take it!
moves.29. Bc3 Rd6xd1 30. Rxd1 Rxd1+ 31. Qxd1 Q: Well, now I have a losing endgame, with an unusual four bishops + queens formation.
moves.32. Qd4 Bg5 33. a5 Bf6 34. Qd2 Bg5 35. Q: This was just not enough firepower, but at least I can inmobilize the WQ to the defence of h3. It costed me leave a pawn to run until the 7th.
moves.41. Kh2 h4 42. Qa1: I can play Ba1, then he Bxg7, etc... no way.
moves.42... hxg3+ 43. fxg3 Qd6: A pawn for a tempo. It seems very "naive", because of an obvious answer, but it can't be played. Can you see because white can't play the "naural" Be5?
moves.44. Be5 Qd2+: Right, for this move. Scratch all little advantage (of plausible) from a desperate position, sac even more (leave white go after the promotion and almost get it... and look to the importance of my c6 pawn...
